item.title: Kurdish-Led Forces End Syria Prison Siege, Defeating ISIS Fighters
item.description: The six-day battle put a spotlight on the humanitarian and security issues left unresolved after the Islamic State’s so-called caliphate was destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian Democratic Forces at the damaged prison in Hasaka on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Offers ‘Diplomatic Path’ in Answer to Russian Demands
item.description: The U.S. response was not made public but Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said it contained “core principles” on Ukraine’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia last month in Sochi, Russia.

item.title: North Korea Launches 2 Ballistic Missiles, South Korea Says
item.description: It was the North’s ​sixth missile test this month, the South Korean military said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Televisions in Seoul showing previous missile launches by North Korea.

item.title: U.K.’s Other Health Crisis: A Huge Backlog of Delayed Non-Covid Care
item.description: The free health care system was known for delays, caused in part by whittled-down funding. But Covid made waits for transplants, cancer treatments and other essential care even longer.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lara Wahab at home in North London. She has been waiting for more than two years for a kidney and pancreas transplant.

item.title: After Coup in Burkina Faso, Protesters Turn to Russia for Help
item.description: Fed up with the failure of their government, and France, to stop the violence caused by militants, some citizens now call for Russia to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds celebrating the military takeover in a plaza in Ouagadougou, the capital, brandished Russian flags and signs that said, “No to France.”

item.title: Boys Held as Hostages by ISIS Worry Rights Activists
item.description: About 700 boys have been held for years in a prison in Syria because their parents joined the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young boys, many under the age of 16, sitting in a crowded cell where they were being held at a prison for former Islamic State members run by Kurdish-led forces in northeast Syria in 2019.

item.title: The World Awaits Putin’s Word on Ukraine, but on That, He Is Silent
item.description: The Russian president appears on camera almost daily, talking about things like cryptocurrency, green energy and the World’s Fair. But not about Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin held a news conference in Moscow last month.

item.title: Here's What US Sanctions on Putin Might Look Like
item.description: The U.S. could seize assets or bar the Russian president from entering the country, but experts say such moves wouldn’t change his thinking.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilyin/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia last year on the Black Sea.

item.title: Palestinian American Held by Israel Died of Heart Attack, Autopsy Shows
item.description: The coroner’s report suggested that Omar Assad, 78, had a stress-induced heart attack as a result of injuries he sustained while in Israeli military custody.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: The funeral for Omar Abdelmajed Assad in the West Bank village of Jiljilya this month. He had hoped to see his family in the United States one more time.

item.title: Awaiting Report on Parties, Johnson Faces Fire Over an Afghan Evacuation
item.description: Email messages made public by Parliament suggest the British prime minister authorized the evacuation of cats and dogs from an animal charity, despite denying doing so.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Killing Spree Spurs Outrage Among Journalists in Mexico
item.description: The killing of three media workers in less than a month triggered protests in cities across the county this week demanding an end to the violence.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: A protest Tuesday in Guadalajara, Mexico, against the recent series of journalist murders.

item.title: Where Is Germany in the Ukraine Standoff? Its Allies Wonder.
item.description: Germany’s allies have begun to question what price Berlin is prepared to pay to deter Russia, and even its reliability as an ally, as it wavers on tough measures.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, in Berlin this month. Mr. Scholz’s Social Democrats have traditionally favored a policy of working with the Russians.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Leaders Are Responding to Russian Threat
item.description: The ‘‘stay calm” posture has left analysts guessing about its leadership’s motivation, but some say that after eight years of war, the country simply calculates the risks differently.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A satellite image showing Russian tanks and artillery tents this month near Voronezh, in southwestern Russia.

item.title: Australian Government Buys Copyright to Indigenous Flag
item.description: The flag had been at the center of a dispute, but the move allows anyone to reproduce its design without seeking permission or paying a fee.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Children with the Aboriginal flag at a demonstration in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday. The flag is regularly flown on government buildings and landmarks.

item.title: U.S. and NATO Respond to Putin’s Demands as Ukraine Tensions Mount
item.description: The formal responses offered President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a choice: negotiate or risk facing punishing economic sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks about Russia and Ukraine during a briefing at the State Department.

item.title: How the Computer Chip Shortage Could Incite a U.S. Conflict With China
item.description: A war game and study by a think tank illustrate how dependent the world is on Taiwan’s semiconductor foundries.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Center for a New American Security
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States and Europe do not have the abilities of mass producing the most advanced designs that the Taiwanese foundry TSMC can make.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Responds to Russia
item.description: Antony Blinken, the secretary of state, said the U.S. offered a “serious diplomatic path forward.”
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: For U.S. Military and Syria's Kurds, a Tangled History as Allies
item.description: American and Kurdish-led forces once beat back the Islamic State in Syria. Now they are fighting together again.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Fighters with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces fighters in Hasaka, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Jana Bennett, Former Director of BBC Television, Dies at 66
item.description: An American-born executive who transformed the presentation of science on TV and was considered one of the most influential women in her industry.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Over her more than three-decade career at the BBC, Jana Bennett assumed responsibility for its domestic and most of its international television networks as well as its entire production machine.

item.title: Macron’s Comments on Algeria Resonate as Elections Loom
item.description: The French president acknowledged the suffering of colonists who fled Algeria after the war of independence, a group that has long voted heavily in favor of the right in France.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron told a group representing families of colonists who fled Algeria that they had experienced a “double punishment,” feeling rejected in Algeria and in France.

item.title: Olavo de Carvalho, Bolsonaro’s Far-Right Guru, Dies at 74
item.description: He was the intellectual leader of Brazil’s far-right movement and a conspiracy theorist who mocked the pandemic. He died days after announcing he had Covid.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Terrance Mccoy/The Washington Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Olavo de Carvalho at his home in Virginia in 2019. Over the past decade, he became one of the most prominent voices behind the growing far-right movement in Brazil.

item.title: Sweden’s Songwriters Look to K-Pop
item.description: Dozens of songwriters and producers in Stockholm make a living from K-pop — even if they can’t speak Korean.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Felix Odell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cazzi Opeia, left, and Ellen Berg at EKKO The Lab in Stockholm on Tuesday.

item.title: Man Faces Weapons Charge in Texas Synagogue Standoff
item.description: The announcement came hours after two men had been arrested in Britain as part of an investigation by counterterrorism officers in which several people have been questioned.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Vimal Patel
item.media:description: The Congregation Beth Israel synagogue in Colleyville, Texas, where four people were taken hostage this month.

item.title: An Extraordinary Iceberg Is Gone, but Not Forgotten
item.description: A chunk of Antarctic ice that was one of the biggest icebergs ever seen has met its end near South Georgia. Scientists will be studying its effects on the ecosystem around the island for some time.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Corporal Phil Dye/RAF/Ministry of Defense, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The iceberg A68a in the South Atlantic near South Georgia in December 2020.

item.title: Diplomats are meeting in Paris under the Normandy Format. We explain.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, in 2019 with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a Normandy Format summit in Paris.

item.title: Germany, Apart
item.description: Donald Trump’s shadow hangs over the Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A U.S. shipment of military equipment arriving in Ukraine yesterday.

item.title: Where Is Peng Shuai? Tennis Players and Fans Still Want to Know
item.description: A central question, “Where is Peng Shuai?”, has represented concern for the star but also points to related questions about the future of tennis in China.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey and Ben Rothenberg
item.media:description: Peng Shuai last played at the Australian Open in 2020.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A flurry of Russian military drills.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A U.S. shipment of military equipment including anti-tank missiles arriving in Ukraine yesterday.

item.title: New Research Hints at 4 Factors That May Increase Chances of Long Covid
item.description: If further study confirms the findings, they could lead to ways to prevent and treat the complex condition.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Gillotte was infected with Covid in March 2020 when he was living in Seattle. He was hospitalized and on a ventilator for several days and experienced long Covid symptoms that lasted for months.

item.title: As ISIS Resurges, US is Drawn Back Into the Fray
item.description: “ISIS is not over”: Attacks in Syria and Iraq make clear that the militants have lost neither their will to fight nor their ability to do so.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American military vehicle patrolling on Monday in Hasaka, Syria.

item.title: U.S. to Bolster Europe’s Fuel Supply to Blunt Threat of Russian Cutoff
item.description: Many European officials suspect President Vladimir V. Putin instigated the crisis in the winter in part to leverage his threat to turn off Russian fuel sales to Europe.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: A construction site of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, near the town of Kingisepp, Russia, in 2019. The country provides about one-third of the gas and crude oil imported by the European Union.

item.title: Guatemalan Militia Men Get 30 Years for Wartime Atrocities
item.description: Five members of a pro-government paramilitary group were convicted of crimes against humanity that were committed against five Indigenous women during the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Jody García
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Women who identify themselves as victims of human rights violations during Guatemala’s civil war applauding outside the Supreme Court in Guatemala City on Monday after the sentencing of five former paramilitary members.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Propaganda War Amid Ukraine Tensions
item.description: The disinformation campaign includes claims that NATO and Ukrainian forces are preparing to attack Russian speakers in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Russian soldiers in the country’s Rostov region, near Ukraine, this month. Russia has produced a steady stream of disinformation about Ukraine since 2014, according to American intelligence officials.

item.title: Dozens Are Reported Missing After Boat Capsizes Off Florida Coast
item.description: The boat, which left the Bahamas on Saturday with 40 people on board, was most likely part of a “human smuggling venture,” the Coast Guard said. One passenger was rescued.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: A man was rescued after he was found straddling the hull of a boat that capsized off Florida’s Atlantic coast, the U.S. Coast Guard said.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Military Drills
item.description: The Kremlin blamed the U.S. for ramping up tensions.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Alexei Ivanov/Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released on Tuesday by the Russian Defense Ministry Press Service of Russian soldiers during a military exercise at the Golovenki training ground in the Moscow region.

item.title: ‘Compartment No. 6’ Review: Strangers on a Russian Train
item.description: A young Finnish woman embarks on a journey of self-discovery that takes her (and you) through richly detailed and surprising terrain.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Frank Dutton, Detective Who Took On Apartheid Crimes, Dies at 72
item.description: A lauded South Africa police official, he dug into cold cases from the days of white rule. “The finest detective that this country has ever produced.”
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Neil Young posts and removes a letter demanding Spotify remove his music.
item.description: “They can have Rogan or Young,” Neil Young wrote to his management team and record label in a letter that he has since removed from his website, according to Rolling Stone. “Not both.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Neil Young called on Spotify to remove his music from the streaming service.

item.title: Heavy Snow Strands Motorists in Greece and Turkey
item.description: In areas more used to dealing with extreme heat, blizzard conditions caused chaos on roads and at airports.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Drivers were stuck on the main Athens ring road on Monday. The heavy snowfall lasted more than 12 hours.

item.title: Kazakhstan’s Longtime Leader Is Gone, but Still Seemingly Everywhere
item.description: Nursultan Nazarbayev, the autocratic former president, all but vanished after violent protests this month. But with his legacy so pervasive, will anything change?
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Playing next to a statue of Kazakhstan’s former president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, in Nur-Sultan, the capital that was renamed in his honor, this month.

item.title: Leprosy Hospital Offers Healing, and a Haven, to the Shunned
item.description: While leprosy is now easily treated, those who have the disease are still often ostracized. But they’re always welcome at this refuge in India, a nation that records over half the world’s cases.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients watching TV in the women’s ward of the Sivananda Rehabilitation Home in Hyderabad, India, in December. The free hospital has been treating leprosy for six decades.

item.title: Australian Aid Ship Docks in Tonga With a Covid Outbreak
item.description: Twenty-three people aboard the ship have tested positive for the virus, prompting concerns that it could spread to Tonga. The volcano-stricken island has reported only one case during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Twenty-three people aboard the H.M.A.S. Adelaide were in isolation after an outbreak was reported on the ship.

item.title: How Do You Pronounce Kyiv?
item.description: “When I see American media, it’s always different, it’s always new, always a surprise,” said a teacher of Ukrainian and Russian languages.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Karen Zraick
item.media:description: At Sophia Square in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Navy Fighter Jet Accident in South China Sea Injures 7
item.description: The military said it was investigating the cause of a “landing mishap” during routine operations.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Petty Officer 1st Class Arthurgwain Marquez/U.S. Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the U.S. Navy of the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson in 2018.

item.title: Israeli Experts Recommend Offering a Fourth Vaccine Dose to People Age 18 and Over
item.description: The Health Ministry cited early signs that a fourth shot might help protect against serious illness, but has yet to approve the panel’s recommendation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Receiving a fourth coronavirus vaccine dose in Tel Mond, Israel, this month.

item.title: A police inquiry into Downing Street gatherings puts more pressure on Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain arriving at Downing Street in London on Monday.

item.title: Two Covid Americas
item.description: The unvaccinated are less worried than the boosted, according to a poll.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for tests in Salt Lake City.

item.title: U.K. Police Say They Are Investigating Downing Street Lockdown Parties
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has come under fire over revelations that he and his staff attended parties while the country was in a coronavirus lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The front pages of British newspapers in London earlier this month.

item.title: C.I.A.-Backed Afghan Fighters Are Still Waiting to Reach U.S.
item.description: Commandos who played a key role in helping American forces are waiting for visas in the United Arab Emirates, and are among the last of the evacuated Afghans to get a chance to reach the United States.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of Afghans waited outside Kabul’s airport in August as they tried to flee the country. Afghan commandos trained by the C.I.A. provided security at the airport.

item.title: Sue Gray’s Report Could Determine Boris Johnson’s Fate
item.description: Sue Gray, who oversees the British government’s ethics inquiries, will deliver a report on Downing Street parties that could topple the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson during a coronavirus media briefing in Downing Street, London, on Jan. 4.

item.title: For Ukrainian Soldiers, a Nervous Guessing Game on the Front
item.description: Given Russia’s penchant for misdirection, it’s unclear how a military incursion would start. And that keeps the Ukrainian troops on edge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a trench on the frontline on Monday in Popasna, Ukraine.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: U.S. troops may be deployed to Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of the 8,500 troops would take part in a NATO response force that might soon be activated, John F. Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, said on Monday.

item.title: Why Is North Korea Suddenly Launching So Many Missiles?
item.description: Experience has shown Kim Jong-un that saber-rattling is the best way to get Washington’s attention, especially when global affairs are already in a precarious state.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the North Korean government showing what it said was a test-fire of a tactical guided missile on Jan. 17.
